narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Fred Strebeigh is unequivocally engaged with the students in a way that not other faculty at FES is, or even tries to be. He is an exemplary teacher and inspires work that is meaningful and high-quality. He also has solid professional experience that he very readily translates into teaching.
Out of any course I've taken at FES, the work and time I put into this class had the greatest output. It's a shame more people can't take this class.

Among the best instructors I've had in my life and certainly at Yale - encompassing both in his theoretical scope and his practical artistry. I owe to Fred some of the best ideas I've had all semester. Being made to write deeply and clearly has improved the depth and clarity of my own thinking.

Question 2: Professor Strebeigh uses an educational method of asking questions to the class about course readings to get students to draw conclusions about the author's intent/meaning/techniques; this (Socratic?) method also has the benefit of forcing students to articulate spoken responses clearly, which is no easy task. There was a bit of grumbling about teaching this way--many students assume that they are being asked for their opinion, not an objective fact about the piece being discussed--but I believe it is necessary and appropriate for a writing class.
I was an auditor so the responses related to work load were answered accordingly.
The class was very useful for me. The teacher is amazingly skilled and helpful. This is not an easy class.
Prof. Strebeigh always responded with thoughtful comments even outside of class time.

This course is ideal for anyone wishing to write for magazine publication, whether in the environmental sciences or not. Fred gives excellent insights into the building blocks of an effective and engaging magazine article, but he allows you to play with your own creativity. I immensely enjoyed this class.

In response to Questions 1-7: this was the best class I've taken at FES. I feel incredibly lucky to have had the chance to work with the professor. How I read, write, and respond to others' writing has fundamentally changed for the better as a result of this class. Professor Strebeigh is the best, most inspiring, and most dedicated professor I've had at FES.

The opportunity to get constant feedback on a piece and write about something you really felt passionate about. It was also great to read other students' pieces and get to know their experiences and writing styles.
The professor's amazingly thorough attention given to each student.
The small group editing process at the end- very useful and enjoyable.Also, excellent feedback from the professor throughout the course.
Finishing with a substantial product that felt, in some way, valuable, worth the effort.
Fred's responsiveness and overwhelming willingness to go out of his way to make sure you succeed. He puts an insane amount of work into this class and it completely pays off.
The course design. The workshop format and gradual transition from reviewing outside pieces to pieces written for the class is stellar.

Excellent comments both from Fred and from my fellows in the class. The readings were helpful, even if I didn't always have time for them. The weekly writing assignments were challenging, but made the second half of the semester much smoother than it would have been otherwise.

The classes were very helpful, as was Professor Strebeigh's personal and detailed comments on articles. I enjoyed the exciting and yet very instructive way that Prof Strebeigh runs the classes - I was able to stay engaged through the whole of the three hour class. The workshop sections of the class were especially instructive and engaging.Also, the front-loading of the writing assignments in the semester was great.

The core content of the course, combined with the breadth of the reading material, is I think integral for non-scientific and environmental communication for general-public audiences. It is, in short, very useful for enviro. professionals.
The in depth analysis of good writing. The course is conducive to participation.
Prof. Strebeigh's comments on each student's weekly submissions.
The instructor is enthusiastically engaged with the progress of his students.
It is well set up, with clear objectives, assignments and pace.The teacher is very good. He can teach.The focus is on skills - writing skills.
The student run workshops were most valuable to me because I enjoyed commenting and critiquing other student work. I believe this helped me to be a more thoughtful writer in my own work.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: It kind of drops off at the end. It would be great to have a class on submitting our pieces to various publications, if people are ready for that step.
Can't think of anything significant.
nothing comes to mind.
More clarity at the outset about how developed a story idea should be for the class. (Starting from scratch is extremely challenging in this class.)

Perhaps break into smaller groups earlier in the semester, or have two sets of smaller groups (so people don't get tired of reading the same pieces). This question is difficult because this class is fantastic and really well organized.

Nothing really, though I'm sure Fred will continue to tweak it. One thought would be that perhaps more weight could be given to writers getting started with there research and interviews in the proceeding summer as it makes the writing go much faster...
The three hour class over dinner might happen at a better time, or should have a 15 minute break in the middle.
No suggestions here.
I would have like the auditing period to be longer.

I like the structure of having the first part of the class together and then breaking apart to work on our own and check in -- but I think students should be able to opt out of the student workshop groups and just check in with Prof. Strebeigh instead. I didn't find the student workshop groups at all helpful.
None that I can think of.
Sometimes class discussions are hard to follow.

This is less a critique about the course, but students thinking of taking this course should recognize that additional outside research is often required for developing a rich piece. This work is additional to writing assignments for the class.

Some time building an atmosphere of trust between students who are sharing their work would have been helpful. Some work on unlocking your creativity, and then effectively channeling and expressing your passions would contribute to even more powerful writing and bolster a lifelong writing practice. Training in how to effectively give feedback to others is also a useful lifelong skill. However, this course very effectively does what it does and I don't see great need to tinker with it.
If at all possible, it would be wonderful to have the readings on-line.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The instructor always returned our assignments on time, which was very much appreciated. It always seemed like he had taken a good amount of time reading each of our submissions and giving valuable feedback. Outside of the assignment schedule, however, it was a bit difficult to get a hold of him in person, although he was always available by phone.
Excellent.
excellent.
Unparalleled attention and help.
Instructor-incredibly available.
The instructor gave weekly, detailed feedback to all students.
Tremendous - Fred puts a herculean effort into providing quick and insightful feedback for his students. The other faculty could learn a lot from him. Perhaps Fred could give workshops...
Professor Strebeigh was incredibly responsive to comments and questions from students.
Very good.
Prof. Strebeigh was very available and extremely helpful.
Professor is accessible.
Awesome. Fred worked hard and was unusually helpful.

As I already indicated, Prof. Strebeigh was very available for discussion and commenting even if I had questions and drafting for him to read outside of assignment due dates. I appreciated the attention and critique that I received for my piece.
The availability and quality o help I received from the instructor was exceptional.
Excellent.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I really wanted to write a piece for popular reading that defended zoos in the context of conservation and the environmental movement. It was great to have a class that let me focus exclusively on this goal!
Policy interest -- writing for general audiences is an important communication skill.
This is one of the most useful, relevant and practical courses I've taken at FES
I'm interested in science writing and environmental journalism.

This course is useful for any student at FES, especially those whose interests include environmental communications. Either a second section of this course, or a similar course more broadly focused on environmental communications, team taught, and including film, radio or other media is desperately needed at FES.

Learning to communicate my ideas and emerging environmental trends, whatever the media, should be an essential skill for environmental professionals. As such, this course - in helping me strengthen my popular professional writing skills has been integral in my course of study. These are the kinds of skills we students are talking about when we say "practical" courses...
I hope to do some type of public relations work for environmental or scientific organizations/interests, so it is highly appropriate.
It doesn't.

Essay / article style writing was not an area of strength for me. It is very different from the usual academic writing we use for most of our papers. This skill is badly needed for the future environmental leaders FES students are.

This course has helped improve my writing skills, which I believe are important for all well-rounded programs. I am not sure that I will specifically pursue writing in the near future, but believe it was very valuable nonetheless.
I hope to use writing to effectively communicate my work in community organizing, science, and policy. Thanks to this course, I have solidified this desire and strengthened my ability to do so.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See answer to previous question.
Because I hope that writing will be a part of my eventual career.
Environmental writing is an important skill and I wanted to hone it.
To learn to write better, hopefully to get a publishable piece in print.
I just wanted to learn to be a better writer for purposes of op-ed writing and the like.
In order to be a better writer. This class definitely helped.

Essay / article style writing was not an area of strength for me. It is very different from the usual academic writing we use for most of our papers. This skill is badly needed for the future environmental leaders FES students are.
The main reason that I took this course was to make time to write -mostly out ofmy own enjoyment of writing.
To refine my writing skills while developing a publishable piece of work. I wanted to disseminate my research through popular press as well as academic publications.
See above.

Mostly yes. My experience in the course was very valuable. I expected my experience in the course to be purely related to improving writing skills, but I also gained significant knowledge about reporting, researching, and interviewing, which was unexpected.
I enrolled in the course to learn more about environmental writing techniques and develop a publishable piece of work. That is exactly what I got from the course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to get the work group together at the end of the course and to have some peer review while polishing up the piece.
opportunity to work with excellent writers and learn from their experiences
Only advantages: individual attention.
Allowed time to go into pieces in depth.
Peer review/editing.

Largely good. It was helpfuly to have regular reviewers who knew you and your piece and saw it evolve over time. In general, we could have spent more time analyzing each other's pieces before class and provide more effective feedback.
The work groups were helpful to get and give in depth feedback on people's work.
I thought the student workshop groups werea waste of time.
N/A
This class is set up for group work in the second part. The group work was key in getting feedback on the piece we were writing. There were no disadvantages.
We did not have group projects, but did have group workshops. These had the advantage of discussing our ideas with our peers.
Working in small groups to polish our environmental writing pieces was an excellent way to interact and collaborate with my peers.

It was great to get feed back on a small scale (rather than in the big group format). However, a bit more structured guidance in how to do so would be helpful. For example, readers could read back to the writers sentences or parts that strike them. And they can try to summarize the impression they get from the piece before the author tries to explain (so the author knows what impression s/he is leaving). These are poor descriptions of many techniques that could be - even quickly - discussed.

Advantages were building stronger relationships with the people in my work group; Professor Strebeigh's suggestions to ask the group about particular parts of my piece was a great way of making the group work more productive.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do all of the assignments on time and stay on track! That way you'll have a really solid piece at the end of the course and you can get the most out of the opportunity.
ONLY take the course if you have a well formed idea about what you'll write on. and DON'T get behind on the assignments.
Have a solid story idea, and ideally contacts, before starting.

The best pieces are those that are about a place you visited (usually over the summer) and what you learned there. In the spring, if you know you want to take this course, be sure to grab contacts' info and write down little details, even for natural scientists. It'll help you a lot when you're trying to write the piece.
Jump in; make this course the course to which you apply your greatest effort.

Start early! The more research, interviews, stories, and contacts you have about your chosen topic the better. Even if you don't end up using them all, they will ensure that the writing is vivid and the message moving.

It is important to have a good idea of what you want to write before starting the class, and probably to have done some interviews / research the summer before, as it is pretty difficult trying to do that research during the semester.
Be able to work every day on your writing piece, even if it is just for several hours. Constant effort is integral to this class.
Get a topic ready early and make it something you enjoy and love.
Helps to know what you're writing about before you start the semester.
Be prepared to do a lot of work.
Do whatever Fred says.
Think carefully about honing your topic early on in the semester.
Have a strong focus and understanding of what your environmental writing piece will be about when you enter the course.
Take it over and over.
